title: The Lamb of God
subtitle: The culmination of 1,500 years of sacrificial system in a single declaration

key_verse.text: The next day John seeth Jesus coming unto him, and saith, Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.

cards.title: The System Everyone Knew
cards.subtitle: When John spoke, every Jew understood instantly
cards.content:
Picture the Jordan River that day. John the Baptist, Israel's most famous prophet, points to an unknown carpenter and says: 'Behold the Lamb of God.'

For the Jewish audience, this phrase activated 1,500 years of collective memory:

‚Ä¢ Every morning and evening, lambs were sacrificed at the Temple in Jerusalem (Exodus 29:38-39). Two daily lambs √ó 365 days √ó 1,500 years = over 1 million lambs.

‚Ä¢ At every Passover, each Jewish family sacrificed their own lamb. The blood on the doorposts was what saved Israel from death in Egypt.

‚Ä¢ On the Day of Atonement (Yom Kippur), the high priest entered the Holy of Holies with lamb's blood to atone for the sins of the entire nation.

When John says 'the Lamb of God,' he's not using a pretty metaphor. He's declaring: 'This is the Final Lamb. The One all the other lambs were pointing toward.'
cards.revelation_key: The sacrificial system was never the final plan. It was an educational shadow pointing to Christ.

cards.title: The Word That Changes Everything: AIR≈åN
cards.subtitle: Not just covering sin, but TAKING IT AWAY

greek_words.meaning: To lift up, bear upon the shoulders, carry away completely
greek_words.revelation:
This verb is crucial. It doesn't say 'covers' (kalypt≈ç) or 'forgives' (aphiƒìmi). It says AIR≈åN - lifts, bears, and CARRIES AWAY.

It's the same word used when the disciples 'took up' the baskets of leftover bread, or when soldiers 'took up' the cross to carry it.

Jesus doesn't put a sheet over your sin so God won't see it. He lifts it from your shoulders, bears it upon His own, walks with it to Golgotha, and buries it in His tomb. When He rises, your sin doesn't rise with Him. IT'S GONE.
greek_words.application: Your guilt, your shame, your past - Christ didn't just forgive it. He REMOVED it. It no longer exists upon you.

greek_words.revelation:
John could have used 'probaton' (adult sheep) or 'arnion' (little lamb). He used AMNOS - the perfect one-year-old lamb, without blemish, the one used in the most sacred sacrifices.

This word connects directly with Isaiah 53:7: 'He is brought as a lamb to the slaughter.' No coincidence. John is declaring: 'This is the Suffering Servant Isaiah saw 700 years ago.'
greek_words.application: Not just any sacrifice will do. Only God's perfect Lamb can completely take away your sin.

cards.revelation_key: The difference between religion and gospel: religion covers sin temporarily; Christ REMOVES it permanently.

cards.title: The Scarlet Thread: From Genesis to John
cards.subtitle: How every lamb pointed toward this moment

timeline.description: God sacrifices animals to cover Adam and Eve's nakedness
timeline.revelation: The first shedding of blood. God shows that without blood there is no covering for sin.

timeline.description: Abraham tells Isaac: 'God will provide himself a lamb'
timeline.revelation: On Mount Moriah (the same place where the Temple would later stand), Abraham prophesies that God will provide His own lamb. He doesn't ask Abraham to provide; God will provide His own.

timeline.description: The Passover: One lamb per family, without defect, blood on the doorposts
timeline.revelation: The lamb's blood is what causes death to 'pass over.' Israel is saved not by their goodness, but by the blood.

timeline.description: The Suffering Servant 'is brought as a lamb to the slaughter'
timeline.revelation: 700 years before Christ, Isaiah sees the Lamb who bears our sins willingly, without opening His mouth.

timeline.description: John points: 'Behold THE Lamb of God'
timeline.revelation: He doesn't say 'a lamb.' He says 'THE Lamb.' The definitive one. The one all the shadows were pointing toward.

cards.revelation_key: Every lamb in the Old Testament was a chapter in the story that culminates in John 1:29. Christ is the answer God was writing for 1,500 years.

cards.title: The Divine Exchange
cards.subtitle: What Christ took away and what He gave you in return
cards.content:
In the Old Testament system, the lamb died IN PLACE of the person. It was substitution. But Christ does something deeper:

üîÑ THE GREAT EXCHANGE:

‚Ä¢ Your sin ‚Üí upon Him (2 Corinthians 5:21)
‚Ä¢ His righteousness ‚Üí upon you

‚Ä¢ Your death ‚Üí He died it (Romans 6:23)
‚Ä¢ His life ‚Üí you live it (Galatians 2:20)

‚Ä¢ Your guilt ‚Üí He bore it (Isaiah 53:6)
‚Ä¢ His innocence ‚Üí covers you

‚Ä¢ Your separation from God ‚Üí He experienced it on the cross ('My God, why hast thou forsaken me?')
‚Ä¢ His intimacy with the Father ‚Üí now is yours ('Abba, Father')

This is not a fair exchange. It's the most unequal exchange in history: He took your worst and gave you His best.

scripture_anchor.text: For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him.

cards.revelation_key: You're not trying to reach God. Christ already completed the journey and brought you with Him.

discovery_questions.question: What sin, guilt, or shame are you still 'carrying' in your life that Christ already TOOK AWAY (air≈çn) 2,000 years ago?
In the divine exchange, Christ took your death and gave you His life. Are you living as someone who died, or as someone who has Christ's life?
1 million lambs were sacrificed in the Temple over the centuries. All pointed toward Jesus. How does knowing He is the Final Lamb change your worship today?

prayer.title: Prayer of Activation
prayer.content: Jesus, my perfect Lamb. Today I receive by faith what John declared: You TOOK AWAY my sin. You didn't cover it, you didn't minimize it - you lifted it, bore it, and carried it away. Today I choose to stop carrying what You already carried for me. Thank You for the unequal exchange: You took my death and gave me Your life. May my life be an echo of gratitude for the Lamb who was slain from the foundation of the world. In the Jesus name, In the Jesus name, Amen.
